[Verse 2: Zach Bryan]

[Verse 3: Zach Bryan, Both]

annotatable.link_title: Dawns by Zach Bryan (Ft. Maggie Rogers)
annotatable.title: Dawns

annotations:
It just dawned on me
 Life is as fleetin’ as the passin’ dawn
 And I shoulda told him twice
 I believe in somethin’ bigger than both of us
 I miss goin’ out to bars, shootin’ stars
 Not worryin’ ’bout what’s left of us, mm

It is now setting in that the relationship passed as quickly as the dawn or day. She now wishes she would have explained her faith in order to try to save the relationship. She now misses the simple times instead of worrying about the fragile state of the relationship

Give me my dawns back
 ’Cause everything that dies makes its way on back
 I lost her last July in a heart attack
 I need one small victory

At this point he is pleading to have the days (dawns) back that he wasted in this relationship. He lost his mother and if he could somehow get days back with her that would be a small victory compared to the days wasted.

’Cause she never said a thing about Jesus
 I miss my mother’s southern drawl
 And her prayin’ through the walls in the evening

It seems random to start talking about his mom in the middle of what’s, up to this point, seemingly a break up song, but Zach as the song goes on, religion and after life become a central theme. Here Zach is saying this girl’s lack of belief in Jesus breaks his heart, because if she’s right, and there is no heaven, then his mom is really gone, and there’s no way to meet her again.
[Verse 1: Zach Bryan]

At this point in the song, as well as the next verse, there is a siren. Zach said in an interview that the siren actually came from outside the building, and wasn’t added.

.jpg)
I’ll be halfway to my best friend’s home
“Everyone I’ve ever loved has either left or died”-From Austin, In the song, Zach is referring to his dead friends and parent. The home is heaven.

Everything that dies makes its way back
 I lost her last July in a heart attack

This line is about Zach’s mother, DeAnn, who passed away from a heart attack in very early August of 2016. It’s possible he changed the lyrics to July in order to fit the flow of the song better.

Zach stated in an interview with the New York Times,

I think my mom dying really solidified the darkness in life to me. It opened that thing in you that’s like, ‘Hey, be a man now.’

And by the time she wakes
 I’ll be halfway to my mama’s home

Zach’s mother DeAnn passed away (hence the “I miss my mothers southern drawl” line that comes shortly after) so he’s likely saying that by the time his ex-lover wakes he’ll be halfway dead/to Heaven where his mama now lives.

description.plain: Following the viral video of her session in Pharrell Williams' master class at New York University’s Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, the final version of Maggie Rogers' “Alaska” is a beautiful balance between folk and dance, with healthy, layered percussion, gorgeous instrumentation, and breathtaking vocals.

body.plain: Following the viral video of her session in Pharrell Williams' master class at New York University’s Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, the final version of Maggie Rogers' “Alaska” is a beautiful balance between folk and dance, with healthy, layered percussion, gorgeous instrumentation, and breathtaking vocals.

songs.title: Alaska (Toby Green Remix)

songs.full_title: Alaska (Sofi Tukker Remix) by Maggie Rogers
songs.title: Alaska (Sofi Tukker Remix)

annotations:
Learned to talk and say
 Whatever I wanted to

This line seems to imply that Maggie felt muzzled in her relationship, and she desperately needed a sense of liberation from whomever was holding her back. So, she found that in herself. She needs to “cut her hair” to avoid intrusive thoughts of her ex. She needs to walk through the frozen landscapes of the 49th state to leave the past as history. In freeing herself of something that tied her down, she may have also mustered the confidence to speak her mind, to say what she wanted.

Oh me, oh my, I thought it was a dream
 So it seemed

When a relationship weighs on you the way it seems this one did Maggie, being able to free yourself from its grasp seems like, well, a dream. Pleasing your pedometer by coping with an extinguished flame via a trek through, arguably, one of the most beautiful landscapes the United States has to offer, is so cathartic that it doesn’t even feel real. Or, at the very least, it may seem that way.

And now, breathe deep
 I’m inhaling
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Leave me be
 I’m exhaling
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh

It’s the same sort of lightness that I was talking about with the hair or the rush of the cold water in the first verse or even being on a dance floor or having this sort of meditation of air. Being able to breathe in. I find that when I’m scared I close off and I have very shallow breath. But when I’m relaxed and when I’m happy and everything is OK, I can breathe fully and I feel more like myself.

And I walked off you
 And I walked off an old me

It’s funny because it was something I was saying colloquially for three years: I would tell people, “Yeah, all this stuff was happening and then I went to Alaska and I just walked it off.” And then all of sudden when I came to write these lyrics, it was just the most obvious thing.

Cut my hair so I could rock back and forth
 Without thinking of you

I have this theory about hair. It’s literally old pieces of you and it’s really thick. I feel like things get caught in it. It holds a lot of energy. So I find a lot of therapy in cutting my hair. For some people, it’s a tattoo or they dye their hair or they change their clothes or they move. For me, its the visceral action of being able to cut it and then its just gone.

I was walking through icy streams
 That took my breath away
 Moving slowly through westward water
 Over glacial plains

We had to get up really early to cross this river because it had been really warm in Alaska that summer and so the glaciers were melting at a faster pace than we had expected. So you have to like wake up when the sun is at its lowest because then the river will be at its lowest also. So I was picturing being in this icy glacial runoff water in the morning and thinking about how difficult that was. And how strange that was and how hard that was, and yet, how important that was for me to find some of my own clarity within everything else that was happening in my life.

Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh
 You and I, there’s air in between

The outro could be interpreted as two people who have drifted apart and there is now air or space in between them.

But it can also be interpreted as someone emerging as a new person and recognizing the difference between who they are now versus who they were in the past.

You (the past me) and I (the present me), there’s air in between (a difference between us).

And now, breathe deep
 I’m inhaling
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Leave me be
 I’m exhaling
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh
 You and I, there’s air in between
 Ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo, ooh-hoo-ooh
 Ooh-hoo-ooh

It’s the same sort of lightness that I was talking about with the hair or the rush of the cold water in the first verse or even being on a dance floor or having this sort of meditation of air. Being able to breathe in. I find that when I’m scared I close off and I have very shallow breath. But when I’m relaxed and when I’m happy and everything is OK, I can breathe fully and I feel more like myself.

Maggie is taking deep breathes, meditating and reflecting on her life.

She inhales and recognizes that she has created distance between herself and another person and she wants to be left alone.

As she exhales and completes a full breath cycle she again recognizes that there is space between her and this other person and that’s okay.

And I walked off you
 And I walked off an old me

It’s funny because it was something I was saying colloquially for three years: I would tell people, “Yeah, all this stuff was happening and then I went to Alaska and I just walked it off.” And then all of sudden when I came to write these lyrics, it was just the most obvious thing.

The “journey” this narrator took allowed them to get over someone significant. At the same time, it also gave them the time and perspective to change who they were as a person and become someone new.

On another note, this could be an allusion to the musical journey Maggie took—going from strictly folk music on previous work like Blood Ballet to her current fusion with electronic music.

Cut my hair so I could rock back and forth
 Without thinking of you

I have this theory about hair. It’s literally old pieces of you and it’s really thick. I feel like things get caught in it. It holds a lot of energy. So I find a lot of therapy in cutting my hair. For some people, it’s a tattoo or they dye their hair or they change their clothes or they move. For me, its the visceral action of being able to cut it and then its just gone.

If your hair grows as you spend time with someone close to you, especially a romantic partner, it can remind you of them.

Maggie proffers the act of cutting that hair as a method of cutting ties with the memories of that special person after the relationship has faded. Rocking back and forth is typically self-comforting response to emotional distress, so the physical existence of the hair while performing this motion was also a reminder of that person.

description.plain:
“Love You For A Long Time” is the first single released following Maggie Rogers' first major-label album, Heard It In A Past Life. The song was originally written the day before the hit song “Light On”.

To no surprise, the song is about love. However, while the song describes a relationship with a particular person, Maggie has stated she hopes its message can have broader reach, saying:

It’s a song about love in all its forms – romantic love, the love I feel for my friends, the love I feel for my band, and the love I’ve shared with all of you.

The song leans more towards a folk or country sound, arguably a departure from the primarily folk-pop sound of Heard It in a Past Life. The instrumentation primarily features an acoustic guitar paired with a drum rhythm. Touches of piano and some twang from a steel guitar can also be heard in the background. Describing the sound in her own words, Maggie said:

I wanted it to sound like the last days of summer. I wanted it to sound as wild and alive as new love feels.

description.plain: As the last song written for Rogers' Heard It In A Past Life, “Light On” addresses the overwhelming transformation from private to public figure that comes with going viral. Following her sudden rise to fame, Maggie details emotions of feeling “ready to break”, but ultimately finding strength in her fans and music allowing her to “leave the light on” for them if they “leave the light on” for her. In a Twitter post teasing the song’s release, Maggie detailed the meaning behind the song: https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/1049431440805556224

song.embed_content: Read “Light On” by Maggie Rogers on Genius
song.title: Light On

album.full_title: Heard It in a Past Life by Maggie Rogers
album.name: Heard It in a Past Life

body.plain: As the last song written for Rogers' Heard It In A Past Life, “Light On” addresses the overwhelming transformation from private to public figure that comes with going viral. Following her sudden rise to fame, Maggie details emotions of feeling “ready to break”, but ultimately finding strength in her fans and music allowing her to “leave the light on” for them if they “leave the light on” for her. In a Twitter post teasing the song’s release, Maggie detailed the meaning behind the song: https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/1049431440805556224

annotations:
And I am finding out
 There’s just no other way
 That I’m still dancing at the end of the day
The only way for her to conquer her own struggles is to stay positive.

Oh, if you keep reaching out
 Then I’ll keep coming back
 And if you’re gone for good
 Then I’m okay with that
 If you leave the light on
 Then I’ll leave the light on (Light on, light on, light on)

Maggie has stated before that this song is a love letter to everyone who was there for her and never left her even when she was in her worst or needed space, including her fans. She is saying with these few words that whenever we need her, she will be there (for friends and family, she will literally be there and for fans, her words will always be with them) but if we stop needing her, she is ok with that, she understands that is because we are ok and that is wonderful.

Would you believe me now if I told you I got caught up in a wave?
 Almost gave it away
 Would you hear me out if I told you I was terrified for days?
 Thought I was gonna break

In an October 2018 Instagram post, Maggie Rogers stated that this song is about her sudden fame and how she struggled to come to terms with it. Here, the “wave” references the feeling of an out-of-control force overtaking her life.

Oh, leave the light on
 Oh, would you leave the light on?

“Leaving the light on” for someone is a “help me, help you” kind of statement. If you didn’t leave the light on for someone else in a room and turned it off on your way out, you’d be leaving them in the dark with no foundation or place to start. Maggie is begging the subject of the song to leave the light on for her so she has somewhere to start in life.

description.plain:
“That’s Where I Am” is the first single of American singer-songwriter Maggie Rogers’s sophomore album, Surrender. Rogers announced the song’s release on April 4th, 2022, four days ahead of its release, and shared a poster for an accompanying music video:
https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/1511042007472484355?s=20&t=zga0cgLD8tyV_rla0M8oLg

body.plain:
“That’s Where I Am” is the first single of American singer-songwriter Maggie Rogers’s sophomore album, Surrender. Rogers announced the song’s release on April 4th, 2022, four days ahead of its release, and shared a poster for an accompanying music video:
https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/1511042007472484355?s=20&t=zga0cgLD8tyV_rla0M8oLg

annotations:
The woman that you once dated
 I couldn’t relate to her glitter and furs

In the original music video, Rogers wears a lot of outfits, including a coat with fur and a glitter bodysuit. So, if she couldn’t relate to her friend’s old girlfriend “glitter and furs,” she has finally come around to the glitzy look.

search_results.title: Fallingwater
search_results.lyrics:
Fallingwater Lyrics[Verse 1]
Hold on, I thought that I could take it from here
Oh, I thought that I was calm in the clear
Now it's getting harder
Hold on, I thought that I was doing so well

description.plain:
“Fallingwater” began as a demo written by Rogers in her Brooklyn apartment in November 2016. Months later, throughout 2017 and 2018, Maggie finished writing and producing the track in several sessions with former Vampire Weekend member Rostam Batmanglij.

The motif of water runs throughout the song as an earthly metaphor for Maggie’s emotion, but the song structure also mirrors the flow of water. It starts gradually, slow and restrained as she pinpoints the moment where she started losing control in a doomed relationship. By the second verse the water is flowing a bit faster, mirrored by the fastened beat and increase in volume. But by the outro the water is falling suddenly – she is escaping from a collapse of emotions, but also flowing towards new things in a final release.

The song was eventually released as a single on May 23, 2018 along with a message from Rogers on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/999313511867183104?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

song.title: Fallingwater

body.plain:
“Fallingwater” began as a demo written by Rogers in her Brooklyn apartment in November 2016. Months later, throughout 2017 and 2018, Maggie finished writing and producing the track in several sessions with former Vampire Weekend member Rostam Batmanglij.

The motif of water runs throughout the song as an earthly metaphor for Maggie’s emotion, but the song structure also mirrors the flow of water. It starts gradually, slow and restrained as she pinpoints the moment where she started losing control in a doomed relationship. By the second verse the water is flowing a bit faster, mirrored by the fastened beat and increase in volume. But by the outro the water is falling suddenly – she is escaping from a collapse of emotions, but also flowing towards new things in a final release.

The song was eventually released as a single on May 23, 2018 along with a message from Rogers on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/maggierogers/status/999313511867183104?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

annotations:
And it’s getting harder
 I’m like falling water,

This hook has a double meaning. On one hand Rogers references the overall arc of the song, saying it’s getting more difficult to resist her emotions. Her being “like falling water” represents how things are finally changing, as if there were something preventing the water from falling that has been removed. On the other hand though, these lines could have a more literal meaning. Water can be gentle and pleasant when in a pool or bath, but in the hands of gravity it can be painful. Think of standing under a tall waterfall. Therefore this line could be referring to how this relationship that may have been gentle and relaxing before, becomes more and more difficult and painful.

description.plain:
“Want Want” is the second single from Maggie Rogers' second major label album, Surrender.
The song was first performed live at the annual Coachella music festival on April 17, 2022.

A month after the performance, Maggie started teasing the song on her TikTok account, in the same way she did with “That’s Where I Am,” the album’s previous single.

On May 25, she announced that the song would be released on June 1, and on her Discord server, she explained how its release date was delayed due to her graduation from Harvard Divinity School. She also revealed that it was the second song written for the album.

Prior to its live debut, the title of the song had been found on Amazon.com on March 30 when Surrender became available for pre-order:



“Want Want” was simultaneously premiered on BBC Radio 1’s Future Sounds with Sian Eleri. Its music video debuted an hour later, and during its premiere, Rogers stated on the live chat that the song was about “sex” and “the power of prioritizing pleasure.”

annotations: When we were in a band and you

This is possibly in reference to Del Water Gap, a band Maggie formed in 2012 alongside S. Holden Jaffe. She wrote and produced the song during the pandemic alongside him, as noted on a Twitter post on 6/2/22.

description.plain: “Say It” is the seventh song off of Maggie Rogers' debut studio album Heard It In A Past Life. It was written by Maggie and two of her friends from college, Tor Miller and Jack Hallenback, a month after graduation. It was inspired mostly by a crush she had at the time, and the “sparkly feeling of possibility” she developed. However, she admitted that nothing ever came out of it, except for this song.

It was written by Maggie and two of her friends from college, Tor Miller and Jack Hallenback, a month after graduation. It was inspired mostly by a crush she had at the time, and the “sparkly feeling of possibility” she developed. However, she admitted that nothing ever came out of it, except for this song.

annotations:
And every time our fingers touched
 I felt like it would be too much
 And too little to hang onto
the feeling of knowing you’re going to fall hard for someone despite the fact that it could end in heartbreak

I knew it when you looked my way
 That I’d be begging you to stay
 I couldn’t say it to myself
 I couldn’t say it to myself
 I felt it burning in the way
 I held on when you pulled away
 I couldn’t say it to myself
 I couldn’t say it to myself
 I couldn’t say it
 I couldn’t just say it

She describes the quick onset of love and connection that sparked when she had her first intimate moment with him – which seems to have been simply a look that made her realize that this was something different than she’d ever had before.
It is hard to admit that she feels this way – whether it be because it is so soon after meeting him or because she’s not ready to have this deep of a connection with someone. Or maybe both.

description.plain: I think this song is about a relationship in which both people know will ultimately fail, yet they keep holding onto what they had and come to terms with the relationship’s imperfections. “New Song” makes me think they’re trying to rewrite their story into something different, to glaze over the fact that the relationship won’t work. They explore this in the first three verses, then I think the refrain offers acceptance: they realize the relationship will never be perfect or work as they’d like it too, and accept the good it offers anyway. The song comes across as a struggle to reach this final understanding – with no chorus, the verses present vignettes as a build up to the refrain, where the resolution of this conflict is acceptance, that they “don’t mind” and will continue to be in one another’s lives, even if they can’t change their ways. There’s something to be said about the last two minutes of the song that release so much emotional tension.
